# Conclusion:

Over time the novel virus had come to be known as the Muutuvirus, aptly named for its initial identification in the muutubats. The multidisciplinary team, along with many Public Health Professionals around the region worked tirelessly to contain the epidemic as much as possible, and eventually the Muutuvirus became a mild and seasonal flu-like virus that caused no deaths in the population. The muubats at the Safari Zone appeared to be cleared of the muutuvirus after much testing and was able to be fully integrated into the wild. The following year, everything returned to normal as much as possible, and Fuchsia City Safari Zone finally opened its doors to tourists again. Many tourists were finally able to see the muubats in nature, and everyone lived peacefully ever after.

## Discussion Fifteen: How did this all begin? The Origins

Tracing the origins of a novel pathogen that sparks an epidemic is often incredibly difficult. This challenge usually stems from a lack of critical information, data gaps, and missing evidence, especially early in an outbreak, making it hard to reconstruct how the initial spillover or transmission occurred.
